executive_summary: The BBQ Sauce Production industry produces liquid or dry seasonings and flavorings. The array of culinary creations incorporating these sauces and rubs shields the industry from economic volatility. As organic foods gain increased traction in the United States, barbecue sauce manufacturers are pivoting to meet demand for all-natural ingredients. Furthermore, the visibility of the industry is boosted by TV shows featuring barbecue competitions. The popularity of outdoor cooking and grilling during COVID-19 led to a revenue boost of 5.6% within the same year. However, decreases in per capita disposable income, reduced meat consumption and dips in the consumer confidence index have negatively impacted revenue.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: BBQ Sauces Meet Meat on the Grill During COVID-19
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Barbecue sauce is typically used in meat preparation; therefore, per capita meat consumption, the amount of meat consumed by an average American over a year, influences the industry's performance. And despite the health risks and the connections between high intakes of red meat and heart disease, certain cancers, and type 2 diabetes, per capita meat consumption is expected to increase from 215.2 pounds in 2017 to 218.9 pounds in 2022. According to the Hearth, Patio and Barbecue Association (HPBA), grill and smoker sales are expected to increase over the coming years. According to the HPBA, 70.0% of US adults own a grill or a smoker.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: PRODUCT VARIETY AND COMPETITION GO HAND IN HAND
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Barbecue sauce, sometimes stylized as BBQ sauce, is a popular condiment choice for meat dishes of all kinds. This industry's product is widely available and popular, from barbecue shacks in small towns to national fast-food chains. New products are being brought to the market to fit in with fresh, healthy eating and various tastes. Americans have become more health conscious. Organic barbecue sauce producers can capitalize on this trend because claims of natural and organic ingredients are attractive to these consumers. The industry is moderately concentrated, with the most prominent producers benefiting from economies of scale as they usually have contracts to produce for restaurants and fast food chains and contracts for key inputs.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: STABLE COSTS AND BALANCED TRADE GROWTH FOSTER STEADY PROFIT
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: On average, producers are expected to experience stable levels of profitability through the end of 2023, in part because of relatively low wages. Typically, the production of barbecue sauce relies much more on quality inputs and production processes than skilled labor; however, companies have recently begun hiring specialized workers to develop new flavors to stay competitive. Barbecue's prominent position in US cuisine helps barbecue sauce producers market themselves successfully in new markets abroad. In contrast, the US appetite for barbecue encourages foreign competitors to send their barbecue products to the United States.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Economic Conditions Will Support an Appetite for BBQ Sauce and Rubs
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Economic conditions will support consumer and restaurant demands. As economic conditions improve over the next five years, more people are expected to buy grills and renovate patio areas, popular for entertaining guests during the warmer months. Per capita disposable income is expected to increase as well. Demand for BBQ sauce and rubs from fast food restaurants is expected to strengthen. Fast food restaurants will continue buying bulk barbecue sauce domestically and abroad. Consumers typically use barbecue sauce to pair with meat dishes. Per capita meat consumption, which measures the amount of meat an average American consumes annually, is expected to rise.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Consumer Preferences Will Drive Product and Spur Innovation
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Consumer preferences for organic, health-conscious and international flavors prompt new products (all-natural, low calorie, low sugar or sugar-free) with international flair (Korean bbq, chipotle, Thai) and versions of original BBQ sauces. To meet consumer preferences for eco-friendly production, packaging and sustainable and responsible sourcing, manufacturers will likely continue to use only ingredients from suppliers meeting specific environmental and social standards. New ways to combine ingredients on the fly (HEINZ REMIX) or in manufacturing meet consumers' preferences for variety.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Small and Large Firms Poised to Meet Changing Demographics and Preferences
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As its exposure via TV shows and competitions expands, barbecue's popularity will likely continue to increase. Many new entrants are expected to be small BBQ sauce producers and enthusiasts selling to local markets to meet increased demand. Millennials are cooking more, compared to some older groups, boosting local grocery purchases and using home food delivery services. Millenials are grillers. In one study by StudyFinds (2022), three-quarters of millennial respondents indicated they have taught older generations to grill certain foods. Many have said they have grilled breakfast and enjoy foods prepared with sauces. People of all ages were reported to find BBQ sauce as versatile, both a dip and marinade.

industry_definition: Barbecue sauce manufacturers make liquid or dry seasonings and flavorings for use on barbecued meat, vegetables and other foods.

negative_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level low - steady

key_trends: Increasing per capita meat consumption boosts demand. Despite health risks associated with high red meat intake, per capita meat consumption is predicted to climb, positively influencing BBQ sauce production industry.
Emphasis on organic, local products inspires innovation
Meeting changing consumer preferences with agility will mitigate volatility
Regulations up the costs of operations
The Southeast and Southwest's rich BBQ culture and favorable climate are a draw

market_segmentation.segment_description: Wholesalers supply to retailers (supermarkets, discount stores, convenience stores, businesses that sell bulk, packaged foods) and comprise the largest market for BBQ sauce manufacturers. Large-scale supermarkets and grocery stores purchasing directly from food manufacturers challenge this market's share. The grocery market is competitive and grocery retailers always seek out cost-cutting methods, establishing their own trucking and warehousing units to buy products directly from food manufacturers. For companies lacking in-house storage and distribution operations, wholesalers still represent an efficient and cost-effective way to market BBQ sauces and rub products.

Sales to traditional grocery stores and supermarkets, including larger supermarket chains, is consumers' most crucial purchase point. Major manufacturers (McCormick) operate their distribution divisions to obtain greater business control and benefit from lower costs. Small local producers will keep selling to smaller markets; some even offer private label services (PepperNutz.com).

Food service professionals (motels, hotels, restaurants, fast food chains and convention centers) experienced significant headwinds in 2020 from COVID-19, impacting some manufacturers. Since many small and medium barbecue sauce producers initially developed their products either for use in their own restaurants or for direct sale, most of these companies make their products directly available to consumers through owned stores or restaurants. Some food service establishments purchase barbecue sauces produced by small and medium businesses. Those sales will most likely be included in this market segment, as these companies generally sell directly to all customers.

This segment includes manufacturers that produce different sauce marinades, savory snack foods, frozen foods and prepared meat and poultry meals and ingredients purchased include dry rub seasonings, dry marinades and sauce mixes. Overall, as the manufacturing sector benefited from rising disposable incomes and a strengthening domestic economy at the beginning of the period, demand from this market improved, causing its market share to expand.

products_and_services.product_description: Original BBQ Continues to Sizzle Many major BBQ manufacturers offer a so-called "original" barbecue sauce. These sauces are Kansas City-style, tomato-based, mildly spiced and often include vinegar and corn syrup, molasses, or sugar. Some companies consider their original barbecue style St. Louis-style, although the flavor profile resembles Kansas City-style. "Original" represents the majority of sales because of the style's popularity and versatility. Even though specialized barbecue sauces are designed for specific cuts of meat or cooking preparations, manufacturers tout the versatility of original sauces for various foods. This segment also includes "light" versions of original sauces and "thick" versions, which contain less water, more sugar and more calories.

Dry barbecue rubs, used to season and tenderize meat before grilling or smoking, impact industry demand because of their versatility. Different product variations cater to unique flavor profiles. Sanitation regulations also influence demand. Since dry rubs are not produced in a temperature-sensitive manner, they are less susceptible to bacterial contamination than BBQ sauces. This compatibility with most states' cottage industry laws allows home-based production and sale, potentially boosting the sector.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Specialty, Regional and Flavored Barbecue Sauces
products_and_services.product_description: Besides Kansas City style, many US regional barbecue styles (Memphis-style, Carolina-style, Texas style) impact barbecue sauce demand. These sauces' flavor profiles, intended meat pairings and ingredient bases cater to various regional preferences and cooking styles. Specialty or flavored sauces, which incorporate unique ingredients like honey, mustard, garlic, brown sugar, or branded products like Jack Daniel's and Dr. Pepper, also influence demand. Growth in the sector is driven by increasing consumer interest in specialty cuisine and the appeal of these sauces as a competitive alternative to popular ethnic seasonings and has witnessed considerable expansion.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Barbecue sauce is a staple in many consumers' kitchens. However, it is not an essential good, and when consumer spending falters, sales of barbecue sauce can be negatively affected. In 2023, consumer spending is expected to increase, representing a potential opportunity for industry operators.

Per capita meat consumption measures the amount of meat consumed by an average American on a yearly basis. Barbecue sauce is typically served with meat dishes so when meat consumption increases, barbecue sauce producers benefit from additional sales. In 2023, per capita meat consumption is expected to increase.

The healthy eating index measures the percentage of a recommended diet that an average American consumes. When consumers are more health conscious, they eat at fast food restaurants less frequently and may avoid barbecue sauce. In 2023, the healthy eating index is expected to rise.

The trade-weighted index measures the relative strength of the US dollar against its trading partners. When the dollar appreciates, foreign goods are more affordable to import and US exports become more expensive to foreign buyers, dampening demand for exports. The trade-weighted index is expected to increase in 2023, posing a potential threat to the industry.

international_trade_points.trade_description: The total value of barbecue sauce imported into the United States has grown. Although barbecue sauce is a quintessentially US product, Canada and Mexico are significant sources of imports. Other Asian-style barbecue sauces are also popular, stirring products from China. Italy is a top importer as consumers continue to embrace exotic flavors and ethnic cuisine.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Low-Cost Operations and Trade Policies Encourage Imports
international_trade_points.trade_description: China benefits from low labor and regulation costs, which enable Chinese producers to charge lower prices. An inflated US dollar has aggravated this trend. Substantial food safety and sanitation regulations from the US government force domestic processors to choose between lowering prices or salvaging profit. Duty-free trade through the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) enables Mexico and Canada to compete with low-priced goods from China and Thailand.

The total value of products exported to foreign countries has. Barbecue sauce is becoming increasingly popular abroad, particularly in emerging markets where barbecue represents classic US cuisine. Large conglomerates have had international operations established for decades, but the burgeoning demand for barbecue sauce abroad is even enabling smaller companies to enter the export market.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Trade Conditions and Transport Costs Matter for Exports
international_trade_points.trade_description: Spurred by duty-free trade under the USMCA a significant share of industry exports end up in the Canadian market, which fully accepts barbecue sauce as a product. Barbecue sauce is less prevalent in Mexico, but exports to that country still generate a sizeable of total export revenue, likely due to the favorable trade conditions.

business_locations.location_description: The West is Tops Because of a Robust Supplier-Customer Network and BBQ Culture - California is the top tomato-farming state in the US. By locating near these regions, BBQ sauce manufacturers can ensure a steady and local supply of preserved tomatoes, reducing shipping costs and ensuring ingredient freshness. - The West has a strong culture and tradition of barbecue. Locating in the West allows producers to cater to regional tastes and preferences. - A large population and vibrant food scene create a robust customer base for BBQ sauce products.

The Saucy Culture of the Southeast and Southwest Spur Establishments - States in the Southeast (North and South Carolina, Tennessee, Mississippi) have a rich barbecue tradition. The local population's knowledge and enthusiasm for barbecue contribute to the region's vibrant production of barbecue sauce.
The Saucy Culture of the Southeast and Southwest Spur Establishments - Southwest's Texas, particularly known for its barbecue culture, has many BBQ sauce establishments.

WEATHER DOES NOT IMPACT MID-ATLANTIC OR GREAT LAKES BBQ MANUFACTURER'S LOCATION CHOICES Great Lakes states (Illinois, Wisconsin) do not enjoy those same weather benefits, but they have meat-centric local cuisines that encourage barbecue sauce demand. Small barbecue sauce producers benefit from being located near their customer base to minimize distribution costs and boost their brand by developing a local reputation.

The Mid-Atlantic region is home to some of the country's biggest and most affluent cities, like New York, making the area very attractive to manufacturers. New York has the third-highest number of industry establishments after California, number one, and Texas, number two in locations.

regulations_points.regulation_description: - The EPA and state governments enforce environmental issues in the food processing industry through federal environmental regulations and statutes. - The EPA is seeking several ways (flexible permits, extending compliance schedules for companies that are proactive in their commitment to reduce pollution) to promote voluntary pollution prevention.
The Clean Air Act is a federal law that sets air quality standards in producing a product and may apply to BBQ sauce manufacturers.

Regulates how processing facilities handle their products and dispose of hazardous and non-hazardous solid waste and may impact BBQ manufacturer's disposal of packaging and any waste generated and transported.

The CWA's regulations for discharging wastewater are the primary regulatory drivers for the food processing industry. Unless located in remote areas, most food processing facilities pre-treat and discharge wastewater directly into a publicly owned treatment plant. When a facility discharges any waste into the environment, it must have a National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System permit as mandated in the CWA.

The FDA governs the food processing industry, primarily for production and labeling standards, through the Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act (FD&C Act) and the Fair Packaging and Labeling Act. The Nutrition Labeling and Education Act, which amended the FD&C Act, requires most foods to bear nutrition labeling. It also requires labels with nutrient content claims and particular health messages to comply with specific requirements.
This program governs and evaluates claims made regarding food products' ingredients and nutritional content. Also, producers must abide by laws and regulations specific to states and counties.

The USDA has established protocols for chemical, microbiological and pathological analysis of food to ensure the safety of specific products. The department has also established specific labeling requirements for barbecue sauces made with meat.

basis_points.basis_description: A robust customer base for local producers spurs individuals passionate about barbecue to enter the market to contribute to local barbecue sauce production.

basis_points.basis_title: Warm climates lead to consistent demand
basis_points.basis_description: Warm climates lead to a consistent demand for grilling and barbecue throughout the year.

Small barbecue sauce producers benefit from being located near their customer base to minimize distribution costs and boost their brand by developing a local reputation. The Mid-Atlantic region is home to some of the country's biggest and most affluent cities, like New York, making the area very attractive to manufacturers.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The four largest industry companies are all major consumer products conglomerates with steady size and revenue growth. These companies hold sizable advantages - large companies have the ability to spend more on product development and marketing than smaller companies. Even though barriers to entry are relatively low, revenue from any one small manufacturer does not capture a significant share of total industry revenue. Even independent companies that produce and distribute nationally (like Sweet Baby Ray's) generate far less revenue than major international conglomerates, keeping larger firm shares stable.

concentration_points.concentration_title: External Competition Has Encouraged Concentration Stability
concentration_points.concentration_description: Substitute products (hot sauce, ethnic sauces) have gained popularity and health concerns about salt and sugar intake have discouraged robust growth in demand for barbecue sauce. As a result, some potential industry producers (small, independent producers) opted to diversify their offerings by manufacturing non-barbecue sauces, thereby staying a minimal contributor to the industry. This strategy by smaller producers further increases the market share generated by the largest barbecue sauce manufacturers. Larger manufacturers also meet changes in consumer preferences and target niche companies to expand their product offerings, especially as consumers begin demanding more ethnic food options and healthier alternatives.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: OTHER OPERATIONS COSTS DIP INTO REVENUE
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Other operations costs (administrative, overhead, research and development) account for an estimated 24.7% of revenue. Companies invest in research capabilities to develop new flavors, additives and preservatives to lower the cost of their products. Distribution costs also form an essential part of the cost structure because many producers directly supply commercial customers and various retail channels to cover as much of the domestic market as possible.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: WAGE COSTS REFLECT THE LOVE OF VARIETY
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Labor costs in the industry are relatively low compared to other sectors and account for an estimated 9.3% of revenue. Shifting consumer preferences and recent trends, companies have had to invest in skilled laborers to develop new flavors and marketing techniques.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: PURCHASES TAKE A BITE OUT OF REVENUE
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases account for an estimated 50.3% of revenue. Organic inputs are more expensive than artificial flavors and preservatives. Still, the most prominent companies are expected to rely more heavily on additives and preservatives because of the scale of their operations. Purchases are expected to increase as a share of revenue as consumers continue to demand higher-quality products.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Capital costs are moderate for this industry, although batches can be made in small quantities, requiring more labor than capital. Existing food manufacturers can easily enter the industry through established plants, extending their product lines with minimal costs.

volatility_points.volatility_title: MEETING CHANGING CONSUMER PREFERENCES WITH AGILITY
volatility_points.volatility_description: This segment also includes "light" versions of original sauces and "thick" versions, which contain less water, more sugar and more calories.

- Shifts in consumer preferences towards healthier or alternative options, like plant-based or low-sugar BBQ sauces, can create volatility for traditional BBQ sauce manufacturers. - Shifts from shocks (COVID-19) that alter demand for products in different ways, i.e., preference for in-home dining to restaurants, will cause a change, depending on the length and nature of the shock. - Capitalizing on changing trends and consumer demands with speedy investment in research and development, product launch and rebranding will curb volatility. Heinz Remix machine, soon to be introduced in various locations, allows consumers to mix their sauces. BBQ is one of the base options, giving Heinz important information on consumer trends.

volatility_points.volatility_description: - In a competitive marketplace where there are a multitude of differentiated products and close substitutes, manufacturers are slow to alter prices to boost revenue when consumers can switch to another brand. - Companies may enter into contracts that will stabilize the cost of essential ingredients and stabilize prices and volatility, while shifts in prices of essential inputs will boost volatility for manufacturers without contracts.

FAQs.question: How is your company affected by rising imports?
FAQs.answer: Increases in imports as a share of domestic demand, indicates strong consumer demand for a variety of ethnic BBQ flavors produced overseas.

FAQs.question: Have exports offered an opportunity for your company?
FAQs.answer: Increases in exports as a share of revenue indicate strong demand for US-made BBQ sauce, which is viewed as a US staple and often associated with Southern states.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing heavily in research and development to meet changing consumer preferences?
FAQs.answer: Research and development is growing in this industry as companies try and create new and innovative flavors to keep up with consumer taste and trends that are constantly changing.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored acquisition opportunities in areas with well-established infrastructure?
FAQs.answer: As merger and acquisition activity increases, companies look to other companies that already participate in the industry to avoid having to build more manufacturing facilities.

FAQs.question: How has your company leveraged new technology to its advantage?
FAQs.answer: Barbecue sauce producers rely on technology to produce higher quality goods and improve efficiency. For example, companies used microscopic mixing technology to create sauces with better flavors and shelf-stability.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Larger companies benefit from automation; however, there are many small, local companies in the industry. As a result, these companies spend more on wages because they do not have the resources or means to purchase heavy equipment and packaging machines.

FAQs.question: How have international tariffs impacted your ability to import and export products?
FAQs.answer: BBQ sauce falls under other tomato-based sauces, which can incur a tariff.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: Several industry associations, such as the US Small Business Administration and the Association for Dresses and Sauces, support operators in their attempts to remain compliant with regulation.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Profit margins have increased recently as larger companies introduced new premium products, such as regional and ethnically flavored barbecue sauces.

FAQs.question: What percentage of your customers renew their contracts?
FAQs.answer: Larger companies benefit from contracts with large clients, such as restaurants, food chains and supermarkets. Therefore, success is contingent on these contracts being renewed and clients not turning to a competitor for its barbecue sauce needs.

FAQs.question: Do you have contacts with key distributors and end users? Are you located close to your target markets and suppliers?
FAQs.answer: Producers will need to have ties to downstream retailers to ensure a steady market presence. Major companies can access markets easily through established contracts, but small, independent companies will need to diligently build and maintain their markets.

FAQs.question: How can you improve your company to receive better word-of-mouth recommendations? How many of your clients were referred to you by a satisfied client?
FAQs.answer: Since the industry is moderately concentrated, operators will benefit from establishing a clear market niche. Small companies are more likely to succeed if they can identify a market need (e.g. a regional or taste preference) and exclusively cater to it.

FAQs.question: How do you cater your product mix to consumer trends? Do you have any new products in development?
FAQs.answer: All major industry companies offer product lines with multiple product varieties. To stay competitive and best leverage investments in manufacturing equipment, industry operators should offer a wide range of product flavors and styles.

FAQs.question: How can you expand your product portfolio to adhere to consumer preferences? Do you monitor the healthy eating index?
FAQs.answer: The healthy eating index measures the percentage of a recommended diet that an average American consumes. When consumers are more health conscious, they eat at fast food restaurants less frequently and may avoid barbecue sauce.

FAQs.question: Does demand for your company's products rise as meat consumption increases? How do you plan to mitigate this threat?
FAQs.answer: Per capita meat consumption measures the amount of meat consumed by an average American on a yearly basis. Barbecue sauce is typically served with meat dishes so when meat consumption increases, barbecue sauce producers benefit from additional sales.

FAQs.question: How is your establishment affected when consumer spending is high? How do you encourage purchases from price-conscious consumers?
FAQs.answer: Barbecue sauce is a staple in many consumers' kitchens. However, it is not an essential good, and when consumer spending falters, sales of barbecue sauce can be negatively affected.
